question: Jesus...
answer: What's in the case?

question: I'm sorry?
answer: You're always lugging that case around. I'm curious. What do you sell?

question: I'm... in restaurant supplies. I didn't get your name?
answer: Must travel a lot, huh? Whole country, or just hereabouts?

question: I don't mean to be rude but--
answer: How's your wife feel about it?

question: What?
answer: She must get lonely, with you gone all the time. Does she?

question: Look, I...
answer: Do you get lonely? Ya miss fucking her, Harold?

question: Listen, I don't know who you are but you can't--
answer: Did it myself. It's sort of a hobby. I've got more. Would you like to see them? Tell me Here. This one's my favorite. Really says it all, wouldn't you agree?

question: You're a... You're sick.
answer: That's a matter of opinion.

question: You're sick! I'm having a problem - with another customer. I'd like you to ask him to leave, please. He's-- What-do-you-want?! What-do-you-want-with- me?!
answer: There's a rest stop, next off-ramp. Pull into it.

question: I have some money. It's not a lot but--
answer: Nobody wants your money, Harold. Just pull in.

question: Why?!
answer: Because I don't wanna do this at 70 miles an hour. It could be dangerous.

question: Oh. Thanks.
answer: Mackelway! You gonna sit on your ass all day, or do you wanna do something?

question: Ya run the plates? Hey! What the fuck're you doing?! You guys ever heard of evidentiary procedure?
answer: Did the right thing, Agent Mackelway. Let's have a look. What's that?

question: Sir? Sort of a... stickler for procedure.
answer: I imagine you would be.

question: Hold it a second. Smells like... clove.
answer: Field Office. Dallas. Christ...

question: Movin' right along.
answer: Okay. Whadda we know?

question: Picked up a foot-print in the back seat of Speck's car, size-and-a-half bigger than Speck's.
answer: 'Kay.

question: We ought to work out some kind of protocol.
answer: For what?

question: Interviews. Witnesses. Looks pretty silly, our talking over one another.
answer: Fine. I'll handle them from now on.

question: Trunk's ajar.
answer: Why eyelids?

question: Huh?
answer: No other signs of torture here. Why take somebody's eyelids off?

question: So they can't blink. It's a metaphor - to make certain the victim sees... or to make certain that we see something. Or maybe it's just a fuck-you. I'm sorry about Don.
answer: Huh?

question: You're not wearing your ring anymore. Hello?
answer: Agent Mackelway? Benjamin spent hours down here.

question: Did he have access to those?
answer: No. They're staff-only.

question: Would you mind opening them for me? He was here... seven years you said?
answer: Off and on. It's not uncommon for our guests to vanish for months at a time.

question: I ran the name through our database, just to be sure. There's never been an Agent Benjamin O'Ryan in the Bureau.
answer: No... but as elaborate fantasies go, it was one of my favorites. And he always seemed so sincere about it.

question: Is that what you called him? Benjamin?
answer: It's what he wished to be called. That one's mine. He painted one of the walls in his room, too.

question: Can I see it?
answer: We've painted it over.

question: Still, might be helpful. Wait. Yes, Sir. They assured me that they understood protocol.
answer: I guess you fellas're never unaccounted for, huh?

question: Huh?
answer: Anything urgent?

question: No.
answer: Ever seen a fifty-foot shark?

question: I'm sorry?
answer: Fifty-foot shark. Ever seen one?

question: No.
answer: Doesn't mean there aren't any.

question: Did you know him? The guy who used to stay upstairs. "O'Ryan." Did you know him?
answer: Why? Is he dead?

question: I don't...
answer: You said "Did." Is he dead?

question: Oh. I mis-spoke. No, he's not dead... You know him? He ever talk about this? A circle with a slash through it?
answer: That's not a circle. It's a zero.

question: Sir? We got an i.d. yet?
answer: Mmm-hmm. Might wanna find yourself a fender. You're gonna need to sit down. It's Virgil Ray Starkey.

question: Starkey did this?
answer: No. Starkey's the one on the ground.

question: Whadda we know about the map?
answer: It matches the faxes, Sir. Almost perfectly.

question: Why's Greenville in blue?
answer: Only city where the date on the fax and the date on the map didn't correspond. Fax lists the date of disappearance as August 7. On the map he's written "10- 26."

question: Any of these bodies been recovered?
answer: Two so far. Female, disappeared from Dayton, Ohio on April 12. And a male, Trenton, New Jersey, January 5th. But both bodies were found over a thousand miles from where they'd last been seen. One in Montana, the other in Oregon. Got autopsy reports on both.

question: Either of the bodies have the zero on them?
answer: No, Sir.

question: No, Sir.
answer: Why you?

question: Huh?
answer: He could be sending these to any agent in any office in the country... But he's sending them to you. Why?

question: I don't know.
answer: This is Agent Kulok. Who's calling? Do you know a professor named Daitz? Says he's from Tulane.

question: Yeah. Criminal Psych. I've been trading e- mails with him.
answer: One moment, please...

question: Professor Daitz?
answer: Yes? Agent Mackelway. Come in... ...The name of this theory was "Suspect Zero." The idea of Suspect Zero posits that if a serial killer were diabolical enough, he could traverse the country without ever being caught, killing randomly. Tell me, what makes a killer catchable?

question: Patterns, repetition of behavior.
answer: Now imagine a killer with no patterns, no tell-tale fetishes, no rituals, no hidden desire to be caught. A perfect vessel of evil, killing without ever leaving a single meaningful clue in his wake... He'd be immune to capture, wouldn't he? Your task forces, your forensics teams - they'd be helpless.

question: Is that something you believe in, Professor? Evil?
answer: As a citizen of the world, it's hard not to. Wouldn't you say? Evil is all around us, I think - a part of the natural order of things. Like gravity. Like wind. A vast black wave, corrupting everything it touches. A virus invades a cell, causing it to dysfunction. Perfectly logical. But did it ever occur to you that something may have invaded that virus, something capable of using it to mutate so powerfully? Just because something's invisible to us doesn't mean it doesn't exist. Have you ever seen a fifty-foot shark?

question: I'm sorry?
answer: A shark, as we know, will only attack humans if he runs out of food. But biologists have theorized that for a shark of fifty feet the ocean would be an endless buffet. He'd never run out of food, so he'd have no need to come to the surface. Consequently, we would never see him. Do you follow? We'll never see one. But that doesn't mean they don't exist. Hence Suspect Zero. Some of my colleagues think I'm fascinated with evil. I think the truth is just the opposite Excuse me.

question: We're gonna need everything you can remember about this guy, Tom. Physical description, any kind of distinguishing characteristics.
answer: Where is he?

question: The suspect fled. Couple janitors walked in on it. They're fine. But the description they gave of him wasn't worth a damn. Case you're curious the real Professor Daitz is on sabbatical, out of the country. We can't find him. Whose idea was it to meet there?
answer: His, Sir.

question: Uh-huh. Did he ask you to come alone?
answer: No, Sir.

question: But you figured you'd get a bigger pat on the head if you wrapped this whole thing up without any help - is that it?
answer: Sir, I'm the one who took the call. Agent Mackelway was acting under the assumption that I'd already checked the guy out. We're both to blame.

question: Did Agent Mackelway attend the interview unaccompanied?
answer: Yes, Sir.

question: Hi. I can't anymore. Can't sleep?
answer: What was that music?

question: It's Navajo. A song for dead warriors. I never played it for anybody before. Just had a feeling you'd like it.
answer: How?

question: What're you--
answer: I can't get a read on this guy.

question: Huh?
answer: Why is he sending us all this shit? I've got 800 pins in that map, 800 missing people. What's he telling us? He kills a travelling salesman, then a school-teacher. Then Starkey? It doesn't connect.

question: You're a mess...
answer: I'm fine. I'm clear. I just didn't think this could wait. Fran, this guy is trying to point us at something. Starkey's part of it. But the other two don't connect.

question: Did you drive here?
answer: I'm fine! I just need somebody to think this through with me! He wanted to meet me. It's like he was interviewing me somehow. What is that? Then he kills Starkey. So what was he doing with Speck and Fulcher?

question: You wanna come in?
answer: No. No. You come out. Get dressed.

question: Out where?
answer: I dunno. Somewhere. We're right on the edge of this thing.

question: Agent Mackelway?
answer: Mrs. Speck. Just had a few more questions.

question: I'm sorry I don't have more time, Agent Mackelway. It's my PTA Day.
answer: It's fine. I should've called.

question: I hope I was of some help.
answer: You were. Thanks.

question: A friend of mine said I'll feel like this one month for every year we were together. Sort of a grieving rule-of- thumb. Have you ever heard that?
answer: No. Sorry. Oh. There was one other thing

question: No. Why?
answer: It's nothing. Trace elements we found on his trunk. Any interest in chemistry? Maybe as a hobby? Anyway, thank you. And thanks for the coffee. Next time I'll call first, I promise.

question: No trouble at all.
answer: It's okay, Fellas. FBI.

question: It's okay, Fellas. FBI.
answer: Listen to me Cowboy. You have any idea the kind of favors I had to pull with the Abilene cops to cover your ass?!

question: Sir...
answer: Breaking and ENTERING the Speck house without a shred of evidence and NO WARRANT?!

question: The sample I took from Speck's bumper... It's crystallized sulfuric acid mixed with oil of Clove, the clove neutralizes the odor of the acid. It was SPECK not his killer who was hiding something.
answer: Ever ask yourself why a big shot agent from Dallas gets sent down to the Wichita Falls Field Office? I'll give you TWO WORDS... Hell I'll even write it down for ya. "EVIDENTIARY PROCEDURE." Don't talk about it. Learn it. Turns out you were right about this guy. You were right about both of them. But that doesn't change the fact that you went about your business like a rookie. Got it?

question: Hey.
answer: Somethin', huh? Guy with a wife and kids keepin' bodies in his attic?

question: Yeah. You okay?
answer: Yeah. Just... Wondered if you could do me a favor. Her name's Karen Sumpter. We were friends. She disappeared last year. Nobody knows where. She was a little wild, but not like that. Anyway, I know you're gonna be in on the autopsies - of the girls they found over at Speck's. Figured you might see if one of 'em was... If it is, I'd like to be the one to notify her folks. Out families've been friends for years.

question: Sure. Of course.
answer: Thanks... 'Night.

question: Evening.
answer: Evening, Officer.

question: See your license, Sir?
answer: 'Course. Is there a problem?

question: See your registration, please?
answer: Sure.

question: Mind stepping out of the car, please?
answer: Officer, I am carrying something that could be construed as a weapon. I'd like to hand it over, voluntarily, so you won't think I'm trying to conceal anything. Would that be all right?

question: What kind of weapon, Sir?
answer: It's a hunting knife, right here on my hip. I was on my way to the woods. My gear's in the trunk. Would you like me to hand it to you? I don't know what the procedure is for something like this.

question: Take the weapon off your hip, place it on the ground, and kick it toward me.
answer: Happy to.

question: What exactly were you planning on hunting, Sir?
answer: A fifty-foot shark. Ya know, I used to be in law enforcement too.

question: That right?
answer: Mmm-hmmm. FBI. 'Course this was some years ago. Psy Ops. Classified.

question: Had anything to drink tonight, Sir? Under medication of any kind? Sir?
answer: Oh. Sorry. Just found myself wondering what was inside that truck.

question: Sir, I'm going to ask you to hand me the keys to your vehicle, please.
answer: Of course.

question: Kulok.
answer: He really was FBI.

question: Huh?
answer: O'Ryan. He left his file on my doorstep. Fran, he was FBI.

question: That's impossible.
answer: I'm look at his whole history! Citations, letters of commendation, even his fucking test scores from Quantico. The guy was an agent.

question: I don't believe it.
answer: Listen to me-- Shit! Hold on. Yes?

question: Where are you? Shit! That was him.
answer: He called you at home?

question: Yes.
answer: Jesus. Call me back.

question: O'Ryan?
answer: I've found him, you know.

question: Who?
answer: Zero.

question: Zero's a myth. You made him up.
answer: Myths don't kidnap little boys. Do they?

question: Do you?
answer: Was she pretty?

question: Huh?
answer: I could hear her moaning, right under the Navajo chanting. Whole thing was downright tribal. What's she look like?

question: You tell me.
answer: Fair enough. We'll stick to business

question: Huh?
answer: "Hope House." You were there. Dyson re-paint it? My room. Did he re-paint it?

question: Yeah. White.
answer: ...But you saw what was underneath, of course.

question: No. Tell me about it.
answer: No. You tell me.

question: Got one of those pins in Denton yet? O'Ryan was spotted there tonight. Took a squad-car and a side-arm from a State Trooper. 'Bout an hour later a five-year old boy was abducted, roughly a mile up the Interstate. The vehicle was found in an abandoned lot. We're establishing a perimeter around the city now.
answer: But the Trooper wasn't hurt...

question: What makes you so sure?
answer: Professional courtesy. Is that... possible, Sir? An agent can just be deleted?

question: Looks like it.
answer: I couldn't understand it before - pushing Speck's car onto the state line. Makes sense now. He wanted to make the case Federal. He's drawing us in.

question: Why would he do that?
answer: So we'd be paying attention when he found Suspect Zero.

question: Ya know what? I'm getting extremely tired of hearing that word. In fact, that's gonna be policy from now on. No Zero.
answer: Sir, profile the guy. He's straight outta Quantico. All he's doing is working a case, like we would. He's not kidnapping little kids - he's chasing the guy who's doing the kidnapping! Look at the map!

question: What're you saying - that all these abductions are the work of one guy? Do you know how fucking insane that is?! Not let's try something that actually makes sense
answer: What if it isn't? What if there really is a Zero out there and O'Ryan's the one guy who's got a shot at him?

question: Fuck's sake, Mackelway - when did you start buying into this guy?!
answer: He's smarter than we are.

question: Speak for yourself.
answer: Sir? What if I told you I knew how to catch him?

question: Do you?
answer: And what if I told you that the way I'd catch him involved sitting in a dark room, with nothing in front of me but a pad of paper... until I'd tapped into some kind of... energy out there. The collective unconscious. Something. If I told you I thought I could target and locate him, without ever leaving this building, what would you say?

question: I'd say you'd watched too many "X-Files."
answer: Y'ever heard of a project called "Icarus," Sir?

question: No.
answer: Agents, trained to "see" distant locations using nothing but the mind. They called it Remote Viewing. Army stole it from the Soviets. The Bureau stole it from the Army - used it to track serial killers. Experimental program. O'Ryan was the first agent they recruited.

question: Good for him.
answer: Voodoo, right? Pure Bullshit. ...except, it worked. It's how he drew this He'd never been in that house before. He just saw what was in there - the Bureau taught him how... same one that deleted him. Same one that's trying to catch him now... Does anything about all this strike you as odd?

question: I'm going to Denton at Oh-Six-Hundred. You can take the day off. Does he listen to you?
answer: I'm sorry?

question: It's not a strength of his. I'm noticing that lately.
answer: He's fine.

question: I'm not so sure. You oughtta sit him down, remind him how a chain-of-command works.
answer: He's fine, Sir.

question: They going to Denton?
answer: Mmm-hmm.

question: But not you?
answer: Sitting in on two autopsies.

question: Oh.
answer: You okay?

question: Yeah. Why?
answer: Nothing.

question: Are they male or female?
answer: Huh?

question: The autopsies.
answer: Females - Logan, Utah; and Decatur, Alabama. So is this what happens when an agent spins out? He gets deleted?

question: Sometimes. The lucky ones get sent to Wichita Falls. Friend of the Receptionist, missing for about a year now. I told her I'd let her know if the body ever turned up.
answer: The Receptionist.

question: Her name's Katie.
answer: I see you got the blue pin out of Greenville.

question: Yeah. Last night. Kid named Simms.
answer: No. I meant her. The girl.

question: What're you talking about?
answer: Did ya look at her vitals? Greenville, Texas. October 26.

question: O'Ryan's in Greenville.
answer: What makes you think so?

question: That's where Zero is. Lloyd Simms - October 26, '99. Karen Sumpter - October 26, 2000. Both disappeared from Greenville. Zero comes back to the same spot, once a year. Today's the 25th.
answer: Wait. When did we establish that Zero was real?

question: O'Ryan thinks so.
answer: Do you?

question: I've seen this before.
answer: Huh?

question: Same burn-mark. I saw it before but it didn't register.
answer: He burns them?

question: I dunno. Almost looks too symmetrical to be a burn. They're autopsying her this morning?
answer: Yeah.

question: He sent a fax from this location 'bout seven o'clock this morning. Are your faxes programmable? Could he have paid last night to have it sent this morning? Were you here last night? 'Scuse me. Mackelway.
answer: It's not a burn. It's a freezer-burn.

question: You're sure.
answer: There's crystallization in the blood stream. The blood never clotted in the wound. It's a freezer burn... I'm having the other body shipped out - the guy from Trenton. We'll see if he's got the same thing.

question: So... he keeps the bodies in a freezer, then buries them...?
answer: I dunno. If he kept them in a freezer they'd have marks like this all over. Wouldn't they?

question: Thanks, Fran. Just some coffee, thanks. Might hit the buffet in a bit. Mackelway.
answer: What're you doing?

question: Surveilling. What're you doing?
answer: Driving to Greenville.

question: Why would you be doing that?
answer: I think agents are safer when they have some company. I can send along Katie if you'd rather.

question: I'm at the truck-stop we traced. Off the
answer: I'm 'bout a half hour out.

question: I'll order some lunch for you. Hear the meatloaf's good today. Dammit! This is Mackelway. I need a run down on a plate. Texas You okay? Kid? You okay in there? I'll be back. Don't worry.
answer: Well, well... Must be quite a moment for you. Congratulations.

question: What're you doing here?
answer: Waiting for you.

question: Hands up.
answer: Awfully conventional - don't ya think?

question: Huh?
answer: Apprehend the fugitive, then call it in for your pat on the head.

question: Sorry to disappoint you.
answer: I'll get over it. But I'm not too sure that little boy will.

question: What little boy?
answer: The one from the Diner, in Denton.

question: You know where he is?
answer: I can find him.

question: How?
answer: Same way I found Starkey, and Speck, and Fulcher... and you. I need someplace quiet - someplace I can concentrate... And your assurance that once he's located, we go get him together.

question: I can't do that.
answer: Then I can't help you. I'm talking about uncompromised justice. No trials. No lawyers. No hiccups in a chain of evidence that can set a monster free. You of all people should be able to appreciate the value of that.

question: Where's the boy?
answer: I won't be doing this much longer. Actually, this is the end of it. I've come to accept that. But there is one last thing to--

question: Where's the boy, O'Ryan?
answer: Do we have an understanding?

question: Enough of this shit. Where's the boy?
answer: Good. This is good. Sort of thing you'd never find in a procedural manual. It tells me I was right about you.

question: I will kill you, O'Ryan.
answer: I know. But we have work to do first.

question: Where's the Goddamn kid?!?!
answer: Don't pick that up. This is the guy who put all those pins in that map of yours! And I can take you to him!

question: Fine. Where is he? Where is he?!?!
answer: Right here...

question: Fuck you.
answer: Are you afraid? "Imagine a killer with no patterns, no tell-tale fetishes, no rituals of any kind. No hidden desire to be caught. A perfect vessel of evil." And the name we give that killer... is Zero. Are you afraid? It'd be customary at this point to start praying. I hear a lot of that. Haven't seen too many answers though. I wouldn't hold my breath waiting for another janitor to break in here and save you, either. You're alone.

question: Where's the boy?
answer: My, my. Must be extremely satisfying to watch yourself say something so heroic. I'm almost envious. The boy's under the bed. In pieces. Are you afraid? I know what you're thinking How about now? Are you afraid? Hmmm? Agent Mackelway? Are you? Are you? Are you afraid?! Open your eyes! Open your eyes Goddammit or I'll cut the fucking lids off!! ARE YOU AFRAID?!?! Stand up. It's over now. Can you stand? We really do have to go. This is where he'll be. With the boy. Zero. He's coming home today. We're going to be there. You're ready to come with me now. You've been in the pit. Stand up. Soon. I promise... But not yet. Please... I'm begging you.

question: Tell me about Icarus.
answer: Why?

question: Just... wanna know.
answer: There were five of us. In the program. We'd come in in the morning, have a cup of coffee, talk about the Yankees. Then you'd go to your room, with your pen and your pad of paper, always alone, and you'd try to lock in. Son of Sam. John Wayne Gacy. Ted Bundy. He might be driving his car, or having a beer or brushing his teeth... or cutting someone's eyes out. If you did it right, you got all of it They wired us into this current, the five of us

question: They all wind up like you? The other agents?
answer: No. They're dead now. They broke down. Then they opted out. Killed themselves... After a while, those conversations about the Yankees became impossible. Ya see?

question: I'm sorry.
answer: We're here.

question: Can't bring you in with me. You know that. Those faxes, the Have-You-Seen-Me's... How many of 'em is he actually responsible for?
answer: All of 'em.

question: It's his birthday, isn't it? He comes home on his birthday. Drive. Fuck! This is Mackelway! I'm travelling north on... Grove Road, approaching I-30 in Greenville. Request immediate back-up. Pursuing a suspect in a refrigerated truck, Texas license plate Alpha-- Brakes! Travelling due west now. Don't see a name. It's a service road, running parallel to the-- What're you...
answer: Can't let him hit the Interstate.

question: Get the van open! He's got a kid in the van!
answer: Up. Up.

question: I'll take it from here.
answer: Are you going to shoot him?

question: Give me the gun, O'Ryan.
answer: Shut up. SHUT UP!!! Look at him, Mack. He's not human anymore. Go dig up that old lady's backyard - you'll find bodies there... Maybe hundreds of them. Of course, ya gotta get a warrant first, chain of custody's gotta be followed. One breach, and he walks. My way, he's eliminated; the world is rid of him. It's a lot closer to justice than having some Prosecutor tell you you've left a tissue sample in the wrong lab. Isn't it?

question: Give me the fucking gun!
answer: You have to understand I saw us here. You did too. THUMP! Another violent swing of that tire-iron, busting up the other side of Zero's torso. Now both sides of his rib-cage have shattered. Breathing is almost impossible.

question: Okay. You made your point.
answer: Bullshit! If I'd made my fucking point you would've shot him yourself by now!

question: Enough! Drop it.
answer: Or what?

question: Just drop it.
answer: Would you shoot me?

question: Put it down.
answer: I want you to think for a second. About your destiny. Who you are. You're cursed, like I am - except you keep running from it. You hear things. You see things. That's why you can't sleep, why your head always aches. ...and it's why you are going to let me kill this animal. And then you're going to kill me.

question: Get up.
answer: I can't do that, Mack. I've seen all this already. For months now.

question: Get up.
answer: Every time, we're in this field It's okay. I want you to. I'm begging you to.

question: Every time, we're in this field It's okay. I want you to. I'm begging you to.
answer: Mack?

question: I'm tired, Mack.
answer: Can you hear me?

question: Pull the trigger... I'm not going to jail. Now pull the fucking trigger! Fucking coward. Some things are not up to us to decide. They just exist. They're inevitable. This field. This rain. This moment. It has all already happened. You know that. You've seen it too.
answer: Mack?

question: Shut it off for me.
answer: I'm not going to kill you, O'Ryan.

question: Of course you will. I've seen it.
answer: You saw wrong!

question: You don't understand. Those fucking faces on that map. They call to me. I see their eyes in the dark - they're staring at me
answer: Stop telling me about my fucking destiny!

question: But I've seen it!
answer: Open your eyes, O'Ryan! Here I am, standing here. I'm not shooting you. Doesn't that fucking tell you something? You're a guy with a skill. Period. They taught you more than they should've. I'm sorry about that... But you're not God. You can't see everything.

question: Fine. I'll make it easy for you:
answer: Put the fucking thing down, O'Ryan.

question: Look. It's perfect. Won't even need a hearing this way. You apprehended the suspect in the commission of a murder. Then he turned on you and you fired in self-defense. These things are bigger than you - haven't you seen that yet? Destiny. Justice. Mercy. They're vast. We're just puppets!
answer: I'm not going to kill you!

question: You don't get to decide that!
answer: Yes I do!
